security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown content. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access. The content provides legitimate guidance on building MCP servers.

content.value_statement: Creating MCP servers to connect Claude with external services requires understanding protocol design, proper project structure, and testing strategies. This skill provides a structured four-phase approach to build production-ready MCP servers.
actual_capabilities: Guides through four-phase MCP server development workflow
Provides recommended project structure and TypeScript implementation patterns
Explains tool annotation types for safe tool design
Covers testing with MCP Inspector and evaluation creation
Includes error handling and state management best practices
limitations: Does not execute code or create server files automatically
Does not connect to external APIs or services
Does not provide pre-built server templates
Assumes basic knowledge of TypeScript and command-line tools

use_cases.title: Create Custom Integrations
use_cases.description: Build MCP servers to connect Claude with proprietary APIs and internal services.

use_cases.title: Design Tool Schemas
use_cases.description: Define proper tool annotations and input schemas for reliable tool execution.

use_cases.title: Test Server Quality
use_cases.description: Use MCP Inspector to validate server behavior before deployment.

prompt_templates.title: New MCP Project
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create an MCP server for [SERVICE_NAME]. What is the recommended project structure and what tools should I implement first?

prompt_templates.title: Tool Definition
prompt_templates.prompt: How should I define a [READ-ONLY/DESTRUCTIVE/IDEMPOTENT] tool called [TOOL_NAME] that [FUNCTION_DESCRIPTION]?

prompt_templates.title: Testing Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: What commands should I run to test my MCP server with MCP Inspector and verify my tools work correctly?

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create actionable error messages for my MCP server tools that help users understand what went wrong.

output_examples.input: Help me create an MCP server for a weather API
output: Project structure: src/index.ts, src/client.ts, src/tools/, src/types.ts
Tool annotations: All read-only since weather data is fetched not modified
Transport: Use stdio for CLI, SSE for browser-based clients
Testing: Run npx @anthropic/mcp-inspector to validate tool calls

best_practices: Use descriptive tool names with verbs: get_user_profile, create_document, search_files
Design stateless JSON inputs for better extensibility and debugging
Include actionable error messages with retry guidance or solution links
anti_patterns: Using generic names like doThing, process, or handle for tools
Storing session state on the server side instead of client side
Skipping MCP Inspector testing before deploying production servers

faq.question: Which programming language should I use for MCP servers?
faq.answer: TypeScript with the official SDK is recommended for most use cases. Python developers can use FastMCP.

faq.question: What transport should I choose for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use stdio for local CLI tools, Streamable HTTP for remote servers, and SSE for browser-based clients.

faq.question: How do I test my MCP server before deployment?
faq.answer: Run npx @anthropic/mcp-inspector to interactively test your tools and validate their behavior.

faq.question: Does this skill access external APIs?
faq.answer: No. This is a documentation guide that provides instructions. It does not make any network calls or access files.

faq.question: What tool annotations are available?
faq.answer: Four types: read-only (data retrieval), destructive (modifies data), idempotent (safe to repeat), and open-world (affects external systems).

faq.question: How is this different from pre-built MCP servers?
faq.answer: This skill teaches you to build custom servers for your specific needs. Pre-built servers are available for common services like GitHub and Postgres.
